birds.name: American Robin
birds.description: 9–11 inches. The American Robin is a familiar backyard bird with a gray back, warm orange-red chest, and a cheerful song often heard in early morning.
birds.fun_fact: Robins can tilt their heads to listen for earthworms moving underground before pulling them out.

image.alt: American Robin perched on a branch

birds.name: Northern Cardinal
birds.description: 8–9 inches. The Northern Cardinal is known for its bright red color in males and soft tan coloring with red accents in females, along with a pointed crest.
birds.fun_fact: Unlike many birds, cardinals do not migrate and stay in Pennsylvania year-round.

image.alt: Male Northern Cardinal perched on a branch

birds.name: Blue Jay
birds.description: 9–12 inches. The Blue Jay is a bold blue, white, and black bird known for its loud calls and confident behavior.
birds.fun_fact: Blue Jays can imitate hawk calls to scare other birds away from food.

image.alt: Blue Jay perched on a branch

birds.name: Mourning Dove
birds.description: 9–13 inches. The Mourning Dove is a soft gray-brown bird with a small head and long tail, often seen perched on wires.
birds.fun_fact: Its gentle, sad-sounding call is what gives the Mourning Dove its name.

image.alt: Mourning Dove perched on a branch

birds.name: American Crow
birds.description: 16–21 inches. The American Crow is a large, all-black bird known for its intelligence and strong social groups.
birds.fun_fact: Crows can recognize human faces and remember people who treat them well—or badly.

image.alt: American Crow perched on a branch

birds.name: Downy Woodpecker
birds.description: 5–7 inches. The Downy Woodpecker is a small black-and-white woodpecker with a short beak and light tapping sound.
birds.fun_fact: It is the smallest woodpecker in North America.

image.alt: Downy Woodpecker clinging to a tree trunk

birds.name: Red-bellied Woodpecker
birds.description: 9–10 inches. This medium-sized woodpecker has black-and-white striped wings and a bright red cap on its head.
birds.fun_fact: Despite its name, the red on its belly is faint and often hard to see.

image.alt: Red-bellied Woodpecker on a tree trunk

birds.name: Mallard
birds.description: 20–26 inches. Mallards are large ducks; males have shiny green heads, while females are mottled brown.
birds.fun_fact: Mallards are the ancestors of most domesticated ducks worldwide.

birds.name: Gray Catbird
birds.description: 8–9 inches. The Gray Catbird is a sleek gray bird with a black cap and a rusty-colored patch under its tail.
birds.fun_fact: Its call sounds like a cat’s “meow,” which is how it got its name.

image.alt: Gray Catbird perched on a branch

birds.name: Tree Swallow
birds.description: 5–6 inches. Tree Swallows have glossy blue-green backs and white bellies and are often seen flying gracefully.
birds.fun_fact: Tree Swallows catch insects while flying and skim water to drink.

image.alt: Tree Swallow perched on a twig

birds.name: Dark-eyed Junco
birds.description: 5–6 inches. The Dark-eyed Junco is a small gray bird with a white belly, often seen hopping on the ground in groups.
birds.fun_fact: Juncos are nicknamed “snowbirds” because they often appear when winter arrives.

image.alt: Dark-eyed Junco perched on a twig

birds.name: White-throated Sparrow
birds.description: 6–7 inches. This sparrow has a bright white throat, striped head, and a clear, whistling song.
birds.fun_fact: Its song sounds like “Oh sweet Canada, Canada, Canada.”

image.alt: White-throated Sparrow perched on a twig
